bgp-common-mp-afi-safi-graceful-restart-.description:
BGP graceful restart parameters that apply on a per-AFI-SAFI
basis

enabled.description:
This leaf indicates whether graceful-restart is enabled for
this AFI-SAFI

bgp-common-mp-afi-safi-config.description: Configuration parameters used for all BGP AFI-SAFIs

enabled.description:
This leaf indicates whether the AFI-SAFI is
enabled for the neighbour or group

bgp-common-mp-all-afi-safi-list-contents.description:
A common grouping used for contents of the list that is used
for AFI-SAFI entries

bgp-common-mp-ipv4-unicast-group.description: Group for IPv4 Unicast configuration options

bgp-common-mp-ipv6-unicast-group.description: Group for IPv6 Unicast configuration options

bgp-common-mp-ipv4-labeled-unicast-group.description: Group for IPv4 Labeled Unicast configuration options

bgp-common-mp-ipv6-labeled-unicast-group.description: Group for IPv6 Labeled Unicast configuration options

bgp-common-mp-l3vpn-ipv4-unicast-group.description: Group for IPv4 Unicast L3VPN configuration options

bgp-common-mp-l3vpn-ipv6-unicast-group.description: Group for IPv6 Unicast L3VPN configuration options

bgp-common-mp-l3vpn-ipv4-multicast-group.description: Group for IPv4 L3VPN multicast configuration options

bgp-common-mp-l3vpn-ipv6-multicast-group.description: Group for IPv6 L3VPN multicast configuration options

bgp-common-mp-l2vpn-vpls-group.description: Group for BGP-signalled VPLS configuration options

bgp-common-mp-l2vpn-evpn-group.description: Group for BGP EVPN configuration options

bgp-common-mp-all-afi-safi-common.description: Grouping for configuration common to all AFI,SAFI

prefix-limit.description:
Configure the maximum number of prefixes that will be
accepted from a peer

config.description:
Configuration parameters relating to the prefix
limit for the AFI-SAFI

state.description:
State information relating to the prefix-limit for the
AFI-SAFI

bgp-common-mp-ipv4-ipv6-unicast-common.description:
Common configuration that is applicable for IPv4 and IPv6
unicast

config.description:
Configuration parameters for common IPv4 and IPv6 unicast
AFI-SAFI options

state.description:
State information for common IPv4 and IPv6 unicast
parameters

bgp-common-mp-l3vpn-ipv4-ipv6-unicast-co.description:
Common configuration applied across L3VPN for IPv4
and IPv6

bgp-common-mp-l3vpn-ipv4-ipv6-multicast-.description:
Common configuration applied across L3VPN for IPv4
and IPv6

bgp-common-mp-l2vpn-common.description:
Common configuration applied across L2VPN address
families

srte-policy-ipv4.description:
Configuration and operational state parameters relating to
the SR-TE Policy SAFI for IPv4 Unicast.

srte-policy-ipv6.description:
Configuration and operational state parameters relating to
the SR-TE Policy SAFI for IPv6 Unicast.

bgp-common-mp-all-afi-safi-common-prefix.description:
Configuration parameters relating to prefix-limits for an
AFI-SAFI

max-prefixes.description:
Maximum number of prefixes that will be accepted
from the neighbour

prevent-teardown.description:
Do not tear down the BGP session when the maximum
prefix limit is exceeded, but rather only log a
warning. The default of this leaf is false, such
that when it is not specified, the session is torn
down.

warning-threshold-pct.description:
Threshold on number of prefixes that can be received
from a neighbour before generation of warning messages
or log entries. Expressed as a percentage of
max-prefixes

restart-timer.description:
Time interval in seconds after which the BGP session
is re-established after being torn down due to exceeding
the max-prefix limit.

bgp-common-mp-ipv4-ipv6-unicast-common-c.description:
Common configuration parameters for IPv4 and IPv6 Unicast
address families

send-default-route.description: If set to true, send the default-route to the neighbour(s)

bgp-common-neighbor-group-timers-config.description:
Config parameters related to timers associated with the BGP
peer

connect-retry.description:
Time interval in seconds between attempts to establish a
session with the peer.

hold-time.description:
Time interval in seconds that a BGP session will be
considered active in the absence of keepalive or other
messages from the peer.  The hold-time is typically
set to 3x the keepalive-interval.

keepalive-interval.description:
Time interval in seconds between transmission of keepalive
messages to the neighbor.  Typically set to 1/3 the
hold-time.

minimum-advertisement-interval.description:
Minimum time which must elapse between subsequent UPDATE
messages relating to a common set of NLRI being transmitted
to a peer. This timer is referred to as
MinRouteAdvertisementIntervalTimer by RFC 4721 and serves to
reduce the number of UPDATE messages transmitted when a
particular set of NLRI exhibit instability.

local-as.description:
The local autonomous system number that is to be used
when establishing sessions with the remote peer or peer
group, if this differs from the global BGP router
autonomous system number.

peer-type.description:
Explicitly designate the peer or peer group as internal
(iBGP) or external (eBGP).

auth-password.description:
Configures an MD5 authentication password for use with
neighboring devices.

remove-private-as.description:
Remove private AS numbers from updates sent to peers - when
this leaf is not specified, the AS_PATH attribute should be
sent to the peer unchanged

send-community.description:
Specify which types of community should be sent to the
neighbor or group. The default is to not send the
community attribute

description.description:
An optional textual description (intended primarily for use
with a peer or group

bgp-common-neighbor-group-transport-conf.description:
Configuration parameters relating to the transport protocol
used by the BGP session to the peer

tcp-mss.description: Sets the max segment size for BGP TCP sessions.

mtu-discovery.description:
Turns path mtu discovery for BGP TCP sessions on (true)
or off (false)

passive-mode.description:
Wait for peers to issue requests to open a BGP session,
rather than initiating sessions from the local router.

local-address.description:
Set the local IP (either IPv4 or IPv6) address to use
for the session when sending BGP update messages.  This
may be expressed as either an IP address or reference
to the name of an interface.

bgp-common-neighbor-group-error-handling.description:
Configuration parameters relating to enhanced error handling
behaviours for BGP

treat-as-withdraw.description:
Specify whether erroneous UPDATE messages for which the
NLRI can be extracted are reated as though the NLRI is
withdrawn - avoiding session reset

bgp-common-neighbor-group-logging-option.description:
Configuration parameters specifying the logging behaviour for
BGP sessions to the peer

log-neighbor-state-changes.description:
Configure logging of peer state changes.  Default is
to enable logging of peer state changes.

bgp-common-neighbor-group-multihop-confi.description:
Configuration parameters specifying the multihop behaviour for
BGP sessions to the peer

enabled.description:
When enabled the referenced group or neighbors are permitted
to be indirectly connected - including cases where the TTL
can be decremented between the BGP peers

multihop-ttl.description:
Time-to-live value to use when packets are sent to the
referenced group or neighbors and ebgp-multihop is enabled

bgp-common-neighbor-group-route-reflecto.description:
Configuration parameters determining whether the behaviour of
the local system when acting as a route-reflector

route-reflector-cluster-id.description:
route-reflector cluster id to use when local router is
configured as a route reflector.  Commonly set at the group
level, but allows a different cluster
id to be set for each neighbor.

route-reflector-client.description: Configure the neighbor as a route reflector client.

bgp-common-neighbor-group-as-path-option.description:
Configuration parameters allowing manipulation of the AS_PATH
attribute

allow-own-as.description:
Specify the number of occurrences of the local BGP speaker's
AS that can occur within the AS_PATH before it is rejected.

replace-peer-as.description:
Replace occurrences of the peer's AS in the AS_PATH
with the local autonomous system number

disable-peer-as-filter.description:
When set to true, the system advertises routes to a peer
even if the peer's AS was in the AS path.  The default
behavior (false) suppresses advertisements to peers if
their AS number is in the AS path of the route.

bgp-common-neighbor-group-add-paths-conf.description:
Configuration parameters specfying whether the local system
will send or receive multiple paths using ADD_PATHS

receive.description:
Enable capability negotiation to receive multiple path
advertisements for an NLRI from the neighbor or group

send.description:
Enable capability negotiation to send multiple path
advertisements for an NLRI from the neighbor or group

send-max.description:
The maximum total number of paths to advertise to neighbors
for a single NLRI.  This includes the single best path as
well as additional paths advertised when add-paths is
enabled.

eligible-prefix-policy.description:
A reference to a routing policy which can be used to
restrict the prefixes for which add-paths is enabled

bgp-common-graceful-restart-config.description: Configuration parameters relating to BGP graceful restart.

enabled.description: Enable or disable the graceful-restart capability.

restart-time.description:
Estimated time (in seconds) for the local BGP speaker to
restart a session. This value is advertise in the graceful
restart BGP capability.  This is a 12-bit value, referred to
as Restart Time in RFC4724.  Per RFC4724, the suggested
default value is <= the hold-time value.

stale-routes-time.description:
An upper-bound on the time thate stale routes will be
retained by a router after a session is restarted. If an
End-of-RIB (EOR) marker is received prior to this timer
expiring stale-routes will be flushed upon its receipt - if
no EOR is received, then when this timer expires stale paths
will be purged. This timer is referred to as the
Selection_Deferral_Timer in RFC4724

helper-only.description:
Enable graceful-restart in helper mode only. When this
leaf is set, the local system does not retain forwarding
its own state during a restart, but supports procedures
for the receiving speaker, as defined in RFC4724.

bgp-common-use-multiple-paths-config.description:
Generic configuration options relating to use of multiple
paths for a referenced AFI-SAFI, group or neighbor

enabled.description:
Whether the use of multiple paths for the same NLRI is
enabled for the neighbor. This value is overridden by
any more specific configuration value.

bgp-common-use-multiple-paths-ebgp-as-op.description:
Configuration parameters specific to eBGP multipath applicable
to all contexts

allow-multiple-as.description:
Allow multipath to use paths from different neighbouring
ASes.  The default is to only consider multiple paths from
the same neighbouring AS.

bgp-common-global-group-use-multiple-pat.description:
Common grouping used for both global and groups which provides
configuration and state parameters relating to use of multiple
paths

use-multiple-paths.description:
Parameters related to the use of multiple paths for the
same NLRI

state.description: State parameters relating to multipath

config.description: Configuration parameters relating to eBGP multipath

state.description: State information relating to eBGP multipath

config.description: Configuration parameters relating to iBGP multipath

state.description: State information relating to iBGP multipath

bgp-common-use-multiple-paths-ebgp-confi.description: Configuration parameters relating to multipath for eBGP

allow-multiple-as.description:
Allow multipath to use paths from different neighbouring
ASes.  The default is to only consider multiple paths from
the same neighbouring AS.

maximum-paths.description:
Maximum number of parallel paths to consider when using
BGP multipath. The default is use a single path.

bgp-common-use-multiple-paths-ibgp-confi.description: Configuration parmaeters relating to multipath for iBGP

maximum-paths.description:
Maximum number of parallel paths to consider when using
iBGP multipath. The default is to use a single path

bgp-common-route-selection-options-confi.description:
Set of configuration options that govern best
path selection.

always-compare-med.description:
Compare multi-exit discriminator (MED) value from
different ASes when selecting the best route.  The
default behavior is to only compare MEDs for paths
received from the same AS.

ignore-as-path-length.description:
Ignore the AS path length when selecting the best path.
The default is to use the AS path length and prefer paths
with shorter length.

external-compare-router-id.description:
When comparing similar routes received from external
BGP peers, use the router-id as a criterion to select
the active path.

advertise-inactive-routes.description:
Advertise inactive routes to external peers.  The
default is to only advertise active routes.

enable-aigp.description:
Flag to enable sending / receiving accumulated IGP
attribute in routing updates

ignore-next-hop-igp-metric.description:
Ignore the IGP metric to the next-hop when calculating
BGP best-path. The default is to select the route for
which the metric to the next-hop is lowest

bgp-common-route-selection-options.description: Configuration and state relating to route selection options

route-selection-options.description: Parameters relating to options for route selection

config.description:
Configuration parameters relating to route selection
options

state.description: State information for the route selection options

bgp-common-state.description:
Grouping containing common counters relating to prefixes and
paths

total-paths.description: Total number of BGP paths within the context

total-prefixes.description: Total number of BGP prefixes received within the context

prefix-set-config.description:
Configuration data for prefix sets used in policy
definitions.

name.description:
name / label of the prefix set -- this is used to
reference the set in match conditions

mode.description:
Indicates the mode of the prefix set, in terms of which
address families (IPv4, IPv6, or both) are present.  The
mode provides a hint, but the device must validate that all
prefixes are of the indicated type, and is expected to
reject the configuration if there is a discrepancy.  The
MIXED mode may not be supported on devices that require
prefix sets to be of only one address family.

prefix-set-state.description: Operational state data for prefix sets

prefix-set-top.description:
Top-level data definitions for a list of IPv4 or IPv6
prefixes which are matched as part of a policy

prefix-set.description: List of the defined prefix sets

name.description: Reference to prefix name list key

state.description: Operational state data

prefix-config.description: Configuration data for a prefix definition

ip-prefix.description:
The prefix member in CIDR notation -- while the
prefix may be either IPv4 or IPv6, most
implementations require all members of the prefix set
to be the same address family.  Mixing address types in
the same prefix set is likely to cause an error.

masklength-range.description:
Defines a range for the masklength, or 'exact' if
the prefix has an exact length.

Example: 10.3.192.0/21 through 10.3.192.0/24 would be
expressed as prefix: 10.3.192.0/21,
masklength-range: 21..24.

Example: 10.3.192.0/21 would be expressed as
prefix: 10.3.192.0/21,
masklength-range: exact

prefix-state.description: Operational state data for prefix definitions

prefix-top.description: Top-level grouping for prefixes in a prefix list

prefixes.description:
Enclosing container for the list of prefixes in a policy
prefix list

prefix.description: List of prefixes in the prefix set

ip-prefix.description: Reference to the ip-prefix list key.

masklength-range.description: Reference to the masklength-range list key

state.description: Operational state data for prefix definition

neighbor-set-config.description: Configuration data for neighbor set definitions

name.description:
name / label of the neighbor set -- this is used to
reference the set in match conditions

items.description: List of IP addresses in the neighbor set

neighbor-set-state.description: Operational state data for neighbor set definitions

neighbor-set-top.description:
Top-level data definition for a list of IPv4 or IPv6
neighbors which can be matched in a routing policy

neighbor-sets.description:
Enclosing container for the list of neighbor set
definitions

neighbor-set.description: List of defined neighbor sets for use in policies.

name.description: Reference to the neighbor set name list key.

state.description: Operational state data for neighbor sets.

tag-set-config.description: Configuration data for tag set definitions.

name.description:
name / label of the tag set -- this is used to reference
the set in match conditions

items.description: Value of the tag set member

tag-set-state.description: Operational state data for tag set definitions.

tag-set-top.description:
Top-level data definitions for a list of tags which can
be matched in policies

tag-sets.description: Enclosing container for the list of tag sets.

name.description: Reference to the tag set name list key

state.description: Operational state data for tag sets

generic-defined-sets.description:
Data definitions for pre-defined sets of attributes used in
policy match conditions.  These sets are generic and can
be used in matching conditions in different routing
protocols.

match-set-options-group.description:
Grouping containing options relating to how a particular set
should be matched

match-set-options.description:
Optional parameter that governs the behaviour of the
match operation

match-set-options-restricted-group.description: Grouping for a restricted set of match operation modifiers

match-set-options.description:
Optional parameter that governs the behaviour of the
match operation.  This leaf only supports matching on ANY
member of the set or inverting the match.  Matching on ALL is
not supported

match-interface-condition-config.description: Configuration data for interface match condition

match-interface-condition-state.description: Operational state data for interface match condition

match-interface-condition-top.description: Top-level grouping for the interface match condition

match-interface.description: Top-level container for interface match conditions

config.description: Configuration data for interface match conditions

state.description: Operational state data for interface match conditions

prefix-set-condition-state.description: Operational state data for prefix-set conditions

match-prefix-set.description:
Match a referenced prefix-set according to the logic
defined in the match-set-options leaf

config.description: Configuration data for a prefix-set condition

state.description: Operational state data for a prefix-set condition

neighbor-set-condition-state.description: Operational state data for neighbor-set conditions

match-neighbor-set.description:
Match a referenced neighbor set according to the logic
defined in the match-set-options-leaf

state.description: Operational state data

tag-set-condition-config.description: Configuration data for tag-set condition statements

tag-set-condition-state.description: Operational state data for tag-set condition statements

match-tag-set.description:
Match a referenced tag set according to the logic defined
in the match-options-set leaf

state.description: Operational state data tag-set conditions

generic-conditions.description:
Condition statement definitions for checking
membership in a generic defined set

generic-actions.description:
Definitions for common set of policy action statements that
manage the disposition or control flow of the policy

policy-result.description:
Select the final disposition for the route, either
accept or reject.

policy-conditions-config.description:
Configuration data for general policy conditions, i.e., those
not related to match-sets

call-policy.description:
Applies the statements from the specified policy
definition and then returns control the current
policy statement. Note that the called policy may
itself call other policies (subject to
implementation limitations). This is intended to
provide a policy 'subroutine' capability.  The
called policy should contain an explicit or a
default route disposition that returns an
effective true (accept-route) or false
(reject-route), otherwise the behavior may be
ambiguous and implementation dependent

install-protocol-eq.description:
Condition to check the protocol / method used to install
the route into the local routing table

policy-conditions-state.description: Operational state data for policy conditions

conditions.description: Condition statements for the current policy statement

state.description: Operational state data for policy conditions

policy-statements-state.description: Operational state data for policy statements

policy-actions-state.description: Operational state data for policy actions

actions.description: Top-level container for policy action statements

state.description: Operational state data for policy actions

policy-statements-top.description: Top-level grouping for the policy statements list

statement.description:
Policy statements group conditions and actions
within a policy definition.  They are evaluated in
the order specified (see the description of policy
evaluation at the top of this module.

state.description: Operational state data for policy statements

defined-sets-top.description: Top-level grouping for defined set definitions

defined-sets.description:
Predefined sets of attributes used in policy match
statements

name.description:
Name of the top-level policy definition -- this name
is used in references to the current policy

policy-definitions-state.description: Operational state data for policy definitions

policy-definitions-top.description: Top-level grouping for the policy definition list

policy-definitions.description:
Enclosing container for the list of top-level policy
 definitions

policy-definition.description:
List of top-level policy definitions, keyed by unique
name.  These policy definitions are expected to be
referenced (by name) in policy chains specified in import
or export configuration statements.

state.description: Operational state data for policy definitions

routing-policy-top.description: Top level container for OpenConfig routing policy

routing-policy.description: Top-level container for all routing policy configuration

apply-policy-import-config.description: Configuration data for applying import policies

items.description:
list of policy names in sequence to be applied on
receiving a routing update in the current context, e.g.,
for the current peer group, neighbor, address family,
etc.

default-import-policy.description:
explicitly set a default policy if no policy definition
in the import policy chain is satisfied.

apply-policy-export-config.description: Configuration data for applying export policies

items.description:
list of policy names in sequence to be applied on
sending a routing update in the current context, e.g.,
for the current peer group, neighbor, address family,
etc.

default-export-policy.description:
explicitly set a default policy if no policy definition
in the export policy chain is satisfied.

apply-policy-state.description: Operational state associated with routing policy

apply-policy-group.description:
Top level container for routing policy applications. This
grouping is intended to be used in routing models where
needed.

apply-policy.description:
Anchor point for routing policies in the model.
Import and export policies are with respect to the local
routing table, i.e., export (send) and import (receive),
depending on the context.

state.description: Operational state for routing policy

interface.description:
Reference to a base interface.  If a reference to a
subinterface is required, this leaf must be specified
to indicate the base interface.

subinterface.description:
Reference to a subinterface -- this requires the base
interface to be specified using the interface leaf in
this container.  If only a reference to a base interface
is requuired, this leaf should not be set.

interface-ref-state-container.description:
Reusable opstate w/container for a reference to an
interface or subinterface

state.description: Operational state for interface-ref

interface-ref.description:
Reusable definition for a reference to an interface or
subinterface
Reference to an interface or subinterface

interface-ref-state.description:
Reusable opstate w/container for a reference to an
interface or subinterface

interface-ref.description: Reference to an interface or subinterface

base-interface-ref-state.description:
Reusable opstate w/container for a reference to a
base interface (no subinterface).

state.description: Operational state for base interface reference

interface-common-config.description:
Configuration data data nodes common to physical interfaces
and subinterfaces

description.description:
A textual description of the interface.

A server implementation MAY map this leaf to the ifAlias
MIB object.  Such an implementation needs to use some
mechanism to handle the differences in size and characters
allowed between this leaf and ifAlias.  The definition of
such a mechanism is outside the scope of this document.

Since ifAlias is defined to be stored in non-volatile
storage, the MIB implementation MUST map ifAlias to the
value of 'description' in the persistently stored
datastore.

Specifically, if the device supports ':startup', when
ifAlias is read the device MUST return the value of
'description' in the 'startup' datastore, and when it is
written, it MUST be written to the 'running' and 'startup'
datastores.  Note that it is up to the implementation to

decide whether to modify this single leaf in 'startup' or
perform an implicit copy-config from 'running' to
'startup'.

If the device does not support ':startup', ifAlias MUST
be mapped to the 'description' leaf in the 'running'
datastore.

enabled.description:
This leaf contains the configured, desired state of the
interface.

Systems that implement the IF-MIB use the value of this
leaf in the 'running' datastore to set
IF-MIB.ifAdminStatus to 'up' or 'down' after an ifEntry
has been initialized, as described in RFC 2863.

Changes in this leaf in the 'running' datastore are
reflected in ifAdminStatus, but if ifAdminStatus is
changed over SNMP, this leaf is not affected.

name.description:
The name of the interface.

A device MAY restrict the allowed values for this leaf,
possibly depending on the type of the interface.
For system-controlled interfaces, this leaf is the
device-specific name of the interface.  The 'config false'
list interfaces/interface[name]/state contains the currently
existing interfaces on the device.

If a client tries to create configuration for a
system-controlled interface that is not present in the
corresponding state list, the server MAY reject
the request if the implementation does not support
pre-provisioning of interfaces or if the name refers to
an interface that can never exist in the system.  A
NETCONF server MUST reply with an rpc-error with the
error-tag 'invalid-value' in this case.

The IETF model in RFC 7223 provides YANG features for the
following (i.e., pre-provisioning and arbitrary-names),
however they are omitted here:

 If the device supports pre-provisioning of interface
 configuration, the 'pre-provisioning' feature is
 advertised.

 If the device allows arbitrarily named user-controlled
 interfaces, the 'arbitrary-names' feature is advertised.

When a configured user-controlled interface is created by
the system, it is instantiated with the same name in the
/interfaces/interface[name]/state list.

type.description:
The type of the interface.

When an interface entry is created, a server MAY
initialize the type leaf with a valid value, e.g., if it
is possible to derive the type from the name of the
interface.

If a client tries to set the type of an interface to a
value that can never be used by the system, e.g., if the
type is not supported or if the type does not match the
name of the interface, the server MUST reject the request.
A NETCONF server MUST reply with an rpc-error with the
error-tag 'invalid-value' in this case.

mtu.description:
Set the max transmission unit size in octets
for the physical interface.  If this is not set, the mtu is
set to the operational default -- e.g., 1514 bytes on an
Ethernet interface.

loopback-mode.description:
When set to true, the interface is logically looped back,
such that packets that are forwarded via the interface
are received on the same interface.

interface-phys-holdtime-config.description:
Configuration data for interface hold-time settings --
applies to physical interfaces.

up.description:
Dampens advertisement when the interface
transitions from down to up.  A zero value means dampening
is turned off, i.e., immediate notification.

down.description:
Dampens advertisement when the interface transitions from
up to down.  A zero value means dampening is turned off,
i.e., immediate notification.

interface-phys-holdtime-state.description: Operational state data for interface hold-time.

interface-phys-holdtime-top.description:
Top-level grouping for setting link transition
dampening on physical and other types of interfaces.

hold-time.description:
Top-level container for hold-time settings to enable
dampening advertisements of interface transitions.

config.description: Configuration data for interface hold-time settings.

state.description: Operational state data for interface hold-time.

interface-common-state.description:
Operational state data (in addition to intended configuration)
at the global level for this interface

ifindex.description:
System assigned number for each interface.  Corresponds to
ifIndex object in SNMP Interface MIB

admin-status.description:
The desired state of the interface.  In RFC 7223 this leaf
has the same read semantics as ifAdminStatus.  Here, it
reflects the administrative state as set by enabling or
disabling the interface.

oper-status.description:
The current operational state of the interface.

This leaf has the same semantics as ifOperStatus.

last-change.description:
This timestamp indicates the time of the last state change
of the interface (e.g., up-to-down transition). This
corresponds to the ifLastChange object in the standard
interface MIB.

The value is the timestamp in nanoseconds relative to
the Unix Epoch (Jan 1, 1970 00:00:00 UTC).

interface-counters-state.description:
Operational state representing interface counters
and statistics.

counters.description: A collection of interface-related statistics objects.

in-octets.description:
The total number of octets received on the interface,
including framing characters.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
at re-initialization of the management system, and at
other times as indicated by the value of
'last-clear'.

in-unicast-pkts.description:
The number of packets, delivered by this sub-layer to a
higher (sub-)layer, that were not addressed to a
multicast or broadcast address at this sub-layer.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
at re-initialization of the management system, and at
other times as indicated by the value of
'last-clear'.

in-broadcast-pkts.description:
The number of packets, delivered by this sub-layer to a
higher (sub-)layer, that were addressed to a broadcast
address at this sub-layer.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
at re-initialization of the management system, and at
other times as indicated by the value of
'last-clear'.

in-multicast-pkts.description:
The number of packets, delivered by this sub-layer to a
higher (sub-)layer, that were addressed to a multicast
address at this sub-layer.  For a MAC-layer protocol,
this includes both Group and Functional addresses.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
at re-initialization of the management system, and at
other times as indicated by the value of
'last-clear'.

in-discards.description:
The number of inbound packets that were chosen to be
discarded even though no errors had been detected to
prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer
protocol.  One possible reason for discarding such a
packet could be to free up buffer space.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
at re-initialization of the management system, and at
other times as indicated by the value of
'last-clear'.

in-errors.description:
For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound
packets that contained errors preventing them from being
deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.  For character-
oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of
inbound transmission units that contained errors
preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer
protocol.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
at re-initialization of the management system, and at
other times as indicated by the value of
'last-clear'.

in-unknown-protos.description:
For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of packets
received via the interface that were discarded because
of an unknown or unsupported protocol.  For
character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces that
support protocol multiplexing, the number of
transmission units received via the interface that were
discarded because of an unknown or unsupported protocol.
For any interface that does not support protocol
multiplexing, this counter is not present.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
at re-initialization of the management system, and at
other times as indicated by the value of
'last-clear'.

in-fcs-errors.description:
Number of received packets which had errors in the
frame check sequence (FCS), i.e., framing errors.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
when the device is re-initialization as indicated by the
value of 'last-clear'.

out-octets.description:
The total number of octets transmitted out of the
interface, including framing characters.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
at re-initialization of the management system, and at
other times as indicated by the value of
'last-clear'.

out-unicast-pkts.description:
The total number of packets that higher-level protocols
requested be transmitted, and that were not addressed
to a multicast or broadcast address at this sub-layer,
including those that were discarded or not sent.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
at re-initialization of the management system, and at
other times as indicated by the value of
'last-clear'.

out-broadcast-pkts.description:
The total number of packets that higher-level protocols
requested be transmitted, and that were addressed to a
broadcast address at this sub-layer, including those
that were discarded or not sent.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
at re-initialization of the management system, and at
other times as indicated by the value of
'last-clear'.

out-multicast-pkts.description:
The total number of packets that higher-level protocols
requested be transmitted, and that were addressed to a
multicast address at this sub-layer, including those
that were discarded or not sent.  For a MAC-layer
protocol, this includes both Group and Functional
addresses.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
at re-initialization of the management system, and at
other times as indicated by the value of
'last-clear'.

out-discards.description:
The number of outbound packets that were chosen to be
discarded even though no errors had been detected to
prevent their being transmitted.  One possible reason
for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer
space.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
at re-initialization of the management system, and at
other times as indicated by the value of
'last-clear'.

out-errors.description:
For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound
packets that could not be transmitted because of errors.
For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the
number of outbound transmission units that could not be
transmitted because of errors.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur
at re-initialization of the management system, and at
other times as indicated by the value of
'last-clear'.

carrier-transitions.description:
Number of times the interface state has transitioned
between up and down since the time the device restarted
or the last-clear time, whichever is most recent.

last-clear.description:
Timestamp of the last time the interface counters were
cleared.

The value is the timestamp in nanoseconds relative to
the Unix Epoch (Jan 1, 1970 00:00:00 UTC).

enabled.description:
Indicates that the subinterface is unnumbered.  By default
the subinterface is numbered, i.e., expected to have an
IP address configuration.

unnumbered.description:
Top-level container for setting unnumbered interfaces.
Includes reference the interface that provides the
address information

state.description: Operational state data for unnumbered interfaces

index.description:
The index of the subinterface, or logical interface number.
On systems with no support for subinterfaces, or not using
subinterfaces, this value should default to 0, i.e., the
default subinterface.

name.description:
The system-assigned name for the sub-interface.  This MAY
be a combination of the base interface name and the
subinterface index, or some other convention used by the
system.

subinterfaces-top.description:
Subinterface data for logical interfaces associated with a
given interface

subinterfaces.description:
Enclosing container for the list of subinterfaces associated
with a physical interface

subinterface.description:
The list of subinterfaces (logical interfaces) associated
with a physical interface

index.description:
The index number of the subinterface -- used to address
the logical interface

config.description: Configurable items at the subinterface level

state.description: Operational state data for logical interfaces

interfaces-top.description:
Top-level grouping for interface configuration and
operational state data

interfaces.description:
Top level container for interfaces, including configuration
and state data.

interface.description: The list of named interfaces on the device.

name.description: References the configured name of the interface

config.description:
Configurable items at the global, physical interface
level

state.description: Operational state data at the global interface level

stat-interval-state.description: Reusable leaf definition for stats computation interval

interval.description:
If supported by the system, this reports the time interval
over which the min/max/average statistics are computed by
the system.

min-max-time.description:
Common grouping for recording the absolute time at which
the minimum and maximum values occurred in the statistics

min-time.description:
The absolute time at which the minimum value occurred.
The value is the timestamp in nanoseconds relative to
 the Unix Epoch (Jan 1, 1970 00:00:00 UTC).

max-time.description:
The absolute time at which the maximum value occurred.
The value is the timestamp in nanoseconds relative to
 the Unix Epoch (Jan 1, 1970 00:00:00 UTC).

avg-min-max-stats-precision1.description:
Common nodes for recording average, minimum, and
maximum values for a statistic.  These values all have
fraction-digits set to 1.  Statistics are computed
and reported based on a moving time interval (e.g., the last
30s).  If supported by the device, the time interval over which
the statistics are computed is also reported.

avg.description:
The arithmetic mean value of the statistic over the
time interval.

min.description:
The minimum value of the statistic over the time
interval.

max.description:
The maximum value of the statitic over the time
interval.

avg-min-max-instant-stats-precision1.description:
Common grouping for recording an instantaneous statistic value
in addition to avg-min-max stats

instant.description: The instantaneous value of the statistic.

avg-min-max-instant-stats-precision2-dB.description:
Common grouping for recording dB values with 2 decimal
precision. Values include the instantaneous, average,
minimum, and maximum statistics.  Statistics are computed
and reported based on a moving time interval (e.g., the last
30s).  If supported by the device, the time interval over which
the statistics are computed, and the times at which the minimum
and maximum values occurred, are also reported.

instant.description: The instantaneous value of the statistic.

avg.description:
The arithmetic mean value of the statistic over the
time interval.

min.description: The minimum value of the statistic over the time interval.

max.description:
The maximum value of the statistic over the time
interval.

avg-min-max-instant-stats-precision2-dBm.description:
Common grouping for recording dBm values with 2 decimal
precision. Values include the instantaneous, average,
minimum, and maximum statistics.  Statistics are computed
and reported based on a moving time interval (e.g., the last
30s).  If supported by the device, the time interval over which
the statistics are computed, and the times at which the minimum
and maximum values occurred, are also reported.

instant.description: The instantaneous value of the statistic.

avg.description:
The arithmetic mean value of the statistic over the
time interval.

min.description:
The minimum value of the statistic over the time
interval.

max.description: The maximum value of the statistic over the time interval.

avg-min-max-instant-stats-precision2-mA.description:
Common grouping for recording mA values with 2 decimal
precision. Values include the instantaneous, average,
minimum, and maximum statistics.  Statistics are computed
and reported based on a moving time interval (e.g., the last
30s).  If supported by the device, the time interval over which
the statistics are computed, and the times at which the minimum
and maximum values occurred, are also reported.

instant.description: The instantaneous value of the statistic.

avg.description:
The arithmetic mean value of the statistic over the
time interval.

min.description:
The minimum value of the statistic over the time
interval.

max.description:
The maximum value of the statistic over the time
interval.

avg-min-max-instant-stats-pct.description:
Common grouping for percentage statistics.
Values include the instantaneous, average,
minimum, and maximum statistics.  Statistics are computed
and reported based on a moving time interval (e.g., the last
30s).  If supported by the device, the time interval over which
the statistics are computed, and the times at which the minimum
and maximum values occurred, are also reported.

avg.description:
The arithmetic mean value of the percentage measure of the
statistic over the time interval.

min.description:
The minimum value of the percentage measure of the
statistic over the time interval.

max.description:
The maximum value of the percentage measure of the
statistic over the time interval.

attribute-compare-operators.description:
common definitions for comparison operations in
condition statements

operator.description: type of comparison to be performed

value.description: value to compare with the community count
